Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Imaging plate boundary processes within the Cascadia subduction zone offshore central Washington with open-access marine seismic data
Award.AbstractNarration:
Analysis of the recently-acquired multi-channel seismic (MCS) data will address a series of topics that relate to the structure of the lithosphere and the margin evolution along the central WA portion of Cascadia subduction zone, and how these relate to current seismicity patterns. Advanced processing of the MCS data is expected to identify the depth and character of the plate boundary and the amount of sediment currently being subducted will be assessed. Deformation of strata within the accretionary wedge will be mapped to track longer-term evolution of the plate interactions. Estimates of crustal hydration will be obtained from assumed seismic velocity-porosity relationships and, along interfaces, reflectivity. Maps showing the distribution of methane hydrates in the region will be produced.

Results will provide a framework within which other Cascadia geoscientific studies are conducted, both for seismic processes and tectonic evolution, and are likely to have implications for hazard assessment. While this subduction zone currently has less earthquake activity than other zones around the world, onshore evidence of repeated megathrust events is clear, so it is important to understand the history of of stress buildup (strata deformation) and the extent to which fluids along faults might enable periods of 'lubricated', slow release.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Cascadia subduction zone encompasses both onshore and offshore regions of the Pacific Northwest of the U.S. and Canada. The potentially hazardous subduction zone fault, known as the Cascadia megathrust, principally lies beneath the offshore region, where the oceanic Juan de Fuca tectonic plate collides with and dives beneath the North American plate, producing earthquakes of up to magnitude 9 accompanied by dangerous tsunamis. Using new geophysical images of the geological structure of the fault zone beneath the seafloor off the coast of the Grays Harbor region of Washington state, generated by seismic reflection sounding to depths of as much as 10 kilometers, we have analyzed the fault geometry, geologic history, and present-day stress conditions in the Cascadia fault and surrounding rocks.

Our study has shown that there is a layer, 2 to 3 kilometers thick, of sediment overlying the igneous crust of the ocean plate, and that layer is almost entirely scraped off and transferred to the continental plate edge when it reaches the subduction zone, forming an “accretionary wedge.” Previously, it was unknown how much of the sedimentary layer might be sliding beneath the fault and under the wedge. This study has shown that only 10-20% at most of that layer goes beneath the wedge. In the southern half of our study area, little to none of it does. This informs our geophysical understanding of what materials are present in the fault zone and how much water-rich sediment gets pushed down the subduction zone to where the earthquakes occur. This in turn sheds light on how the megathrust fault stores up and releases the strain energy during earthquakes.

We also investigated the amount of water (pore fluid) in the sedimentary rocks of the wedge and at its base, and the stress and pore fluid pressure trapped within them. The conditions under which faults slip – and faults stop slipping – at depth in the earth, during major earthquakes, is governed by these stresses and pore fluid pressures in the rock. To understand the likely scale of the tsunami hazard during an anticipated future Cascadia subduction zone earthquake, it is important to be able to predict how likely the slip is to reach all the way out from land to the offshore wedge and trench region. We used seismic wave observations to estimate the stress, water content, and pore pressure. We have found that the wedge probably does not contain elevated pore pressure levels throughout most of its volume, to depth of 3-5 kilometers at the plate boundary fault zone, except in isolated zones. The wedge shape and the evidence for low pore pressure all lead us to conclude that the rock strength in the wedge is high, but also that it slides over a very weak basal fault.

By analogy with other observations from studies of the offshore tsunami-generating earthquakes at Sumatra in 2004, Japan in 2011 and elsewhere, we conclude that our findings mean the Cascadia megathrust fault zone off the coast of Washington is also potentially conducive to the efficient propagation of earthquake slip to the region near the trench in large earthquakes. This would displace the seafloor under the entire continental slope and in turn be conducive to the generation of a relatively large tsunami. 

 


Last Modified: 09/13/2017
Modified by: Harold J Tobin
